DISCUSSIONS WITH FEDERATION OF MALAYA, AND PROTECTION
OF SINGAPORE CITIZENS


    2. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Minister:-

Column: 2474



    (a) whether he has had discussions with the Government of the Federation of Malaya concerning-

    (i) immigration and extradition arrangements;

    (ii) financial and economic matters including income tax; and

    (iii) any other matter of vital interest to Singapore after 31st August, 1957;

    (b) whether he will make a statement regarding the discussions; and

    (c) whether he has taken steps to protect the interests of the citizens of Singapore.

    The Chief Minister: In answer to (a) (i), No, Sir; (a) (ii), Yes, Sir; and (a) (iii), Yes, Sir, In answer to (b), as the matters discussed have not been finalised and have reached a delicate stage, I do not consider it in the best interests to make a statement at the present time. In answer to (c), the hon. Member can rest assured that in all our discussions we are protecting the interests of the citizens of Singapore.

- CONCERN OVER PROPOSED RESTRICTIONS

APPOINTMENTS TO SINGAPORE GOVERNMENT SERVICE
AND RESTRICTION OF PRIVILEGE


    5. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if he is aware that only Federal citizens are eligible to apply for Government or quasi-Government appointments in the Federation of Malaya; and whether he will take steps to ensure that only persons born in Singapore are eligible for appointment to the Singapore Government service, and that this privilege is not extended to persons born in the Federation of Malaya, North Borneo or Brunei.

The position as I understand it is that such persons may be appointed if there are no suitable Federal citizens obtainable and a particular post cannot be left vacant.

COMPLAINTS AGAINST THE POLICE FOR
ASSAULT AND DOMINEERING ATTITUDE


    7. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Secretary whether he is aware that complaints have been made by some suspects, when taken to the Police Stations, that they have been assaulted by members of the Police Force and that the conduct and behaviour of some members of the Force, particularly the recruits, are very domineering; and what action does he propose to take in the matter.

    Mr Goode: Yes, Sir, I am aware that such complaints are frequently made, particularly in secret society cases. Although the conduct of individual members of the Police force may not always be beyond reproach, I do not accept any general imputation against members of the force nor against recruits in particular. Every such complaint is reported to the Commissioner of Police and an immediate enquiry is made and the findings are reported to the Commissioner. I am satisfied that adequate steps are taken to investigate complaints and to take disciplinary action where justified.

NUMBER OF BUSINESS VISITORS SERVED WITH INCOME TAX
NOTICES AND NUMBER WHO PAID TAX


    8. Mr John Ede asked the Financial Secretary

    (a) how many business visitors staying a maximum of seven days in Singapore were served with income tax assessment notices during the first half of 1957; and

    (b) .how many of such persons paid income tax.

    Mr T. M. Hart: Sir, separate lists are not kept of assessments raised in respect of business visitors and the information requested by the hon. Member is therefore not available at the present time. In order to obtain it, it will be necessary to examine all the assessments raised during the first half of 1957. This can be done, but it will mean that staff will have to be taken away from the more important task of

REASONS FOR SERVING INCOME TAX NOTICES ON BUSINESS
VISITORS, AND GOVERNMENT'S POLICY


    9. Mr John Ede asked the Financial Secretary the reasons why business visitors to Singapore are served with income tax assessment notices under section 12 (4) of the Income Tax Ordinance (Cap. 166), instead of being exempted under section 13 (3) ; whether such notices are served on members of official trade missions to this country; and whether he will state the Government policy on this whole matter.

    Mr Hart: Sir, business visitors to Singapore who exercise their employment in the colony are served with income tax assessment notices because the law prescribes that this shall be done. Section 10 (1) of the Ordinance prescribes that tax shall be payable on income derived from the colony in respect of gains or profits from any employment. Section 10 (2) defines gains or profits from any employment. Section 12 (4) prescribes that gains or profits from any employment exercised in the colony shall be deemed to be derived from the colony whether the gains or profits from such employment are received in the colony or not. They cannot be exempted under section 13 (3) for the simple reason that this particular section refers to income arising from sources outside the colony and received in the colony by temporary visitors, and not to the exemption of these visitors from tax.

    Members of official trade missions a reserved with notices if the Comptroller is

Column: 2478

satisfied on enquiry that they are exercising their employment during their visit to Singapore.

    The policy in this matter has recently been under review. It has been noted that other countries with which Singapore has trade relations are perhaps more liberal in their treatment of visiting businessmen. Some countries allow a period which may in some cases amount to a month or two to lapse before such persons become liable to tax on the gains or profits of employment exercised in these countries. It is generally agreed that, in the particular circumstances of Singapore as a centre of communications and trade, it would be desirable to liberalise existing policy to a certain extent. It has therefore been decided to submit the matter to the Malayan Board of Income Tax for consideration under section 3 (5) of the Ordinance. In the meantime, as a temporary measure which will, I hope, have the approval of hon. Members, administrative instructions have been given with effect from 1st August that visiting businessmen who exercise their employment in Singapore will not be served with notices of assessment until they stay in the colony for more than one month.

BILL TO ENABLE FEDERATION CUSTOMS OFFICERS
TO BOARD TRAINS IN SINGAPORE


    10. Mr John Ede asked the Financial Secretary when the Bill will be introduced to enable Federation of Malaya customs officers to board trains at the Singapore Railway Station and make customs examinations en route to Johore Bahru.

    Mr Hart: Sir, in reply to a question from the hon. Member in November of last year, I said that it had already been agreed in principle that Federation customs officers should board trains in Singapore and make customs examinations en route to Johore Bahru, and that a Bill authorising this to be done was in draft. The Bill in question is a revision of the Federated Malay States Customs Duty Collection Ordinance (Cap. 232 in the old edition of the laws), and deals with other matters besides the examination of passengers' goods on

Column: 2479

trains between Singapore and Johore Bahru. This Bill was ready for presentation to the two Legislatures in January 1957 but it was withdrawn by the Federation Government in February so that further amendments to the law could be considered. A redraft was ready in mid-April but it had to be examined by the Departments concerned in Singapore and by the Hon. the Attorney-General in the light of further changes suggested. The present position is that we are awaiting the comments of the Federation Government on a point raised by the Supervisor of Export Duties, Federation Customs Department, in Singapore. I am confident, however, that this point will be settled readily and that the Bill will be presented in the very near future.

NUMBER OF HOUSING UNITS BUILT AND ALLOCATED BY S.I.T.


    11. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing

    (a) whether any houses or housing units and if so, how many, were completed by the Singapore Improvement Trust during the period from January to June 1957; and

    (b) how many of these houses or housing units have been allotted up to 31st July, 1957.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to question (a) is that no houses or housing units were completed. I am informed by the Trust the reason why no houses or housing units were completed during the first half of 1957 is that there were no available vacant sites during a period in 1956 which would have allowed for completion in 1957. I am further informed, Sir, that on 31st July, 1957, over 4,000 units of housing accommodation were in course of construction and contracts had been let out for a further 1,000 units of accommodation.

    The answer to question (b) follows from my answer to (a) - that as no housing units were completed, no houses were allotted.

    13. EXORBITANT RENTS CHARGED BY LANDLORDS,
AND PROTECTION FOR SUB-TENANTS


    14. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he is aware that some landlords and chief tenants sublet rooms at exorbitant rents, and whether he will take steps to protect sub-tenants from being victimized.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware that some landlords and chief tenants sublet rooms at rents higher than they should but in respect of rent-controlled houses at least the remedy is in the hands of sub-tenants who claim they are being victimised. I would draw the hon. Member's attention to the provisions of the Control of Rent Ordinance (Cap. 242), particularly section 15 (1) (g), which prohibits a chief tenant from receiving for the whole of any sublet premises, including the apportioned rental or value of any part of the premises retained by him, more than 110 per cent of the rent he is paying to the landlord. In other words, where a chief tenant pays his landlord a rent of

Column: 2482

$100 per mensem, he is allowed under the Ordinance to collect for all the parts sublet and the part retained by him a total rent not exceeding $110 a month excluding municipal charges. If he collects more than this, a sub-tenant can apply to the Rent Conciliation Board set up under the Ordinance to apportion the rent amongst themselves or to recover any excess paid over the legal rent due.

COMPLAINTS OF RUDE TREATMENT BY HOSPITAL STAFF

As regards the first part of the question, I am not aware of any such complaints. Regarding the

STEPS TO REDUCE PRICES OF RICE AND SUGAR


    19. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he has taken any steps to ensure reductions in the prices of rice and sugar since the reopening of the Suez Canal to shipping.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, perhaps the hon. Member has failed to realise that our imports of rice do not pass through the Suez Canal, and only a minor portion of our sugar imports pass through the Suez Canal. The closing or reopening of the Suez Canal has therefore had only a negligible direct effect on the prices of rice and sugar. The prices of these commodities in Singapore are governed by world supply and demand. In these circumstances, therefore, no action is necessary.

    In further amplification of my reply, Sir, I may perhaps with profit refer the hon. Member to a news item appearing in today's Straits Times under the heading, "Bangkok Clamp May Send Rice Price Up". It states in the news item that there is a possibility of export restrictions in Bangkok which might cause prices to rise in Singapore and the Federation.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Not only the Minister but every other thinking man in Singapore realises that rice and sugar are essential commodities, and if the hon. Member has any bright ideas he may perhaps care to discuss with me.

TRANSFERS BETWEEN ESTIMATE SUBHEADS
(Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 29 of 1957)
(Statement by the Financial Secretary)


10.22 a.m.

    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): Sir, I beg leave to refer to Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 29 of 1957 which has been tabled today and to make some remarks in explanation of it.

    The annual estimates which form an appendix to the Appropriation Ordinance indicate in detail how the funds made available each year should be spent. These estimates, however, have been drawn up in the year previous to that to which they refer. It is not always possible to say with complete accuracy how much will have to be spent in the following year on the services for which provision is made or what new needs will arise.

    As hon. Members are aware, when the need to provide for some new service arises, an application is made for a supplementary vote. Similarly, where there has been some radical change in a service for which provision has already been made and additional funds are required, an application for supplementary vote is made. These applications are incorporated in messages which are presented to the Assembly from time to time.

    There are, however, a number of occasions when the need arises to supplement a service for which provision has already been made but where the additional sum required is small; for example, a rise in the price of printing

Column: 2486

machines due to circumstances in the supplying country may necessitate a supplement; freight rates may be increased as a result of an international crisis and prices may rise generally on goods ordered from overseas; and so on. In no case is any new principle involved, nor has there been any material change in the service for which provision has been made in the estimates.

    It is an established principle in financial procedure of the United Kingdom that the Executive should have power to transfer funds from one service to another provided no new or novel principia is involved and the sum voted under a particular head of expenditure is not exceeded. This power of virement, as it is called, has been incorporated to a limited degree in the financial procedure of this Colony, and General Orders of the Government prescribe - General Order 662(b) -

    "When the provision under one sub-head appears to be likely to be exceeded in any year, savings from another sub-head within the same sub-division of expenditure may be transferred with the approval of the Financial Secretary, except under the Head - 'Public Works, Non-Recurrent'."

    These transfers approved by the Financial Secretary under General Order 662 (b) are recorded in the Treasury and in the Vote Books of the Departments concerned, and are notified to the Deputy Director of Audit as they are made.

    Recently, when studying the accounts for 1954, the Public Accounts Committee of this Assembly drew attention to the fact that, while they had a record of applications for supplementary provision which had been approved, neither they nor the Legislature had any record of transfers approved under General Order 662 (b), and that the information required to reconcile the sums voted in the annual estimates and the expenditure shown in the accounts was to that extent incomplete. It was therefore suggested by the Committee that a quarterly return of transfers under General Order 662 (b) should be made to the Legislature for information. The first return was tabled as Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 16 of 1957 and the second, for the second quarter of the year, is tabled today.

PRIVATE MEDICAL BENEFIT ORGANISATIONS
(Legislation to Control Activities)
(Statement by the Chief Minister)


10.26 a.m.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am pleased to announce that following upon the findings of a Government Inter-Departmental Committee which was recently appointed to look into the nature and activities of private medical benefit organisations, Government has decided in principle to introduce fresh legislation to bring under more effective control the activities of these organisations as well as other forms of mutual-aid organisations which might be established in future.

    Sir, there are at present 21 active medical benefit organisations which have all sought and obtained official recognition by either registering under the Business Names Ordinance or registering as private limited companies under the Companies Ordinance, and except for registration they are not subject to any control whatever. In view of the multiplicity of the activities of these organisations, and public concern as to the questionable nature of some of their objects, it has been decided that it would be necessary to bring these organisations under more effective control; hence the need for the introduction of fresh legislation. The form, Sir, which such legislation will take is now being examined by the Hon. the Attorney-General.

LABOUR (AMENDMENT) BILL
Motion for Introduction, and First Reading


10.31 a.m.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That leave be given to introduce a Bill to amend the Labour Ordinance, 1955 (No. 40 of 1955).

    When this House passed the Labour Ordinance in 1955, it was its intention to give workmen seven full days' leave per year - seven full days not including Sunday or the rest day - and that intention was expressed in section 47 (1) of the Ordinance which reads as follows:

    "Every workman shall be entitled to seven days' paid leave for every twelve months continuous service with the same employer after the coming into force of this Ordinance and such leave shall be in addition to the holidays to which such workman is entitled under section 46 of this Ordinance."

Column: 2489



    Sir, the art of draftsmanship is a very esoteric art and I do not pretend to be an expert in it. Unfortunately the draftsman of this Ordinance, who was supposed to have been an expert, should have expressed the intention of the Legislature accurately and precisely. A matter has now arisen in this way.
